author: Gavin Finch
title: Ex-UBS Trader Hayes Has Asperger’s, Judge Says Before Testimony
text:
Former UBS Group AG trader Thomas Hayes was diagnosed with Asperger’s syndrome, which means he tends to only see the world in black and white, a judge told jurors just before Hayes took the witness stand.
People with the condition do not see shades of gray and have difficulty in social situations, Judge Jeremy Cooke said Tuesday. The answers he gave doctors during a medical assessment were literal, intense and lacking in social niceties, Cooke said. They contained no irony or humor.
The 35-year-old Hayes has pleaded not guilty to eight counts of conspiracy to manipulate the London interbank offered rate, the benchmark used to value more than $350 trillion of loans and securities. Each count carries as much as 10 years in prison.
Hayes, who took the stand for the first time Tuesday, said he had not conspired dishonestly to manipulate Libor. His wife, Sarah, was in the courtroom for the first time in the 28-day trial.
Prosecutors say Hayes persuaded, bullied and cajoled fellow traders and brokers to move benchmark rates to make his positions more profitable. Hayes’s lawyers say the practice was widespread.
Hayes’s ability to understand mathematical patterns is a characteristic of Asperger’s, Cooke said.
